New Records: Kyle Hendricks became the first pitcher in Cubs history to throw at least six innings while allowing two or fewer hits and one or fewer runs in a start at Coors Field, which opened in 1995.
Key Match Events: Michael Busch had his first big league multi-homer game.
Michael Busch hit solo homers in the seventh inning off Jake Bird and the ninth against Justin Lawrence.
Pete Crow-Armstrong hit a two-run homer in the ninth, his 10th home run this season.
Tyson Miller struck out Brendan Rodgers and Ezequiel Tovar for his first career save in four big league seasons.
Post-Match Reflections: Cubs manager Craig Counsell commented on the team's offense, saying, 'We left a small farming village in central Illinois of runners on base, but we played good offense.'

Kyle Hendricks reflected on his performance, stating, 'Stuff moves differently (in Colorado), so you just really focus on execution and stay with it one pitch at a time, and with our lineup and defense, man, you just rely on all the guys around you.'

Rockies manager Bud Black commented on Cal Quantrill's performance, saying, 'He told me during the game and after the game that his arm felt great. It's one of those games over a long season, six months, where he didn't throw strikes.'
Miscellaneous Highlights: Chicago went 3 for 14 with runners in scoring position and stranded 16 runners, tying the major league high for a nine-inning game this season.
Colorado pitchers walked 12 for the first time since a 12-11 win over Milwaukee on June 5, 1999.
